bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Wallach to Philip Showalter Hench, February 21, 1950

div1.p: Wallach informs Hench about the introduction of a joint congressional resolution to honor Reed and his work. Wallach hopes to receive Hench's help in mobilizing various groups who have an interest that this resolution be passed.

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Wallach to Philip Showalter Hench, February 21, 1950
div1.opener:
Telephone: Murray Hill 4-7770
SIDNEY WALLACH ASSOCIATES
Three Eighty One Fourth Avenue, New York 16, N. Y.
February 21, 1950
PUBLIC RELATIONS · MAGAZINE MANAGEMENT · CAMPAIGN PUBLICITY
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am writing to you--and I hope you will forgive the length of the
letter in the light of its contents--after a meeting with General
Walter Reed and Colonel Joseph Siler in Washington, recently. I saw
them in connection with joint congressional resolutions in regard
to Major Walter Reed that had been introduced at this session of
Congress. In the event you are unfamiliar with them, I am enclosing
copies together with a covering memorandum about them.

Both General Reed and Colonel Siler impressed upon me the urgency of
communicating with and, if at all possible, working with you. From what
they told me, I would be only too happy if that could be brought about.
The circumstances of the enclosed resolutions are as follows:

For some time I have been very much interested in the career of Major
Walter Reed and in the achievement that resulted from the work of the
Commission that he headed up. A singular combination of events over a three-
year period: the 50th anniversary of the naming of the Yellow Fever Com-
mission; and of the death of Dr. Reed; and the 100th anniversary of his
birth,--led to the development of the project as described in the resolu-
tions. I brought this proposal to the attention of Senator Jenner of Indiana
(one of the first of the volunteers was, as you know, a private from Indiana).

The Senator was enthusiastic about this proposal. I have since been
working with him towards obtaining early and favorable action by Congress.

It was naturally our desire to make this a non-partisan measure introduced
by a Republican and Democrat, a Senator and a Congressman.

Senator Jenner's office then took the matter up with Congressman Howard
Smith of Virginia. He, too, liked the idea but out of congressional courtesy,
thought that Congressman Bland who represented the district in which Major
Reed was born, should have the opportunity, if he wished, to introduce the
resolution in the House. To this, Congressman Bland agreed.

As it now stands, the Senate Resolution has been referred to the Committee
of Labor and Public Welfare and the House Resolution to the House Rules
Committee.
SIDNEY WALLACH
NATHAN CARO BELTH
IDALEE WALLACH
Dr. Philip Hench

Page two
February 21, 1950

Unfortunately, a complication arose recently with the sudden death of
Congressman Bland. It is, however, my hope that Congressman Smith will
want to carry on, not least, as a courtesy to his late colleague.

I want to acquaint you further with the fact that from my conversations
on Capitol Hill, I have found a considerable measure of support for, and
no opposition to the resolution. What is needed, however, is to have
Senators and Congressmen and particularly members of the two Committees to
which the Resolutions have been referred, receive indications from various
medical bodies, patriotic societies, educational groups, etc., of their
interest. If such public interest is made manifest, our legislators will
act, first in Committee and then in full session. I think there is little
doubt that there would be general approval. The very fact that it is non-
partisan in character is, of course, of great help.

General Reed, to whom I told all this, impressed me with the fact that
you are the one man in the country to whom this might be of significant
interest and who could, if you wished, be of major help.

It is, of course, my hope and that of Senator Jenner, that the resolutions
will pass and that I will head up the program of research, education and
interpretation that the resolutions envisage. In that event, I should
certainly want to work most closely with you. Indeed, I would give a
good deal to have your wholehearted support and cooperation in this project
from the very first.

I should like to add that my hopes go beyond that of the period of the
proposed commemoration. If general public interest can be aroused in the
story of Major Reed and of the Yellow Fever Commission during the three-
year anniversary period, a considerable residue of interest will remain
among private individuals and non-governmental organizations; and much of
this interest and support can be drawn into a sustained program in behalf
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association and of continued scientific work
consistent with the spirit of the work done by Major Reed.

I look forward to hearing from you. I hope, too, that I may have the
pleasure of an early meeting with you as I would like nothing better than
to work closely with you for the success of this project.
